Award.AwardTitle: Protonation and Solvation Studied with Cluster Ion Infrared Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Michael Duncan of the University of Georgia to conduct experimental studies to look at the structure and bonding in complex protonated species. These species are commonly invoked in important reaction mechanisms, like the ever-ubiquitous proton transfer. In these particular experiments, Professor Duncan will use the observed infrared spectra of ions tagged with Ar atoms to infer information about the structure of the protonated species, as well as the strengths of the various bonds (from the vibrational frequencies). The graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will receive training in laser science, molecular beam methods and spectroscopy, while working on compelling chemical problems with broad scientific impact.

Profesor Michael Duncan and his research group will use infrared lasers to photodissociate Ar-tagged protonated species prepared in a molecular beam. The infrared spectrum of these tagged ions is measured by scanning the infrared laser while looking for production of the untagged ion. Species to be studied are: protonated carbonyls, protonated hydrocarbons (carbocations), proton-bound dimers, simple mimics of solvated species. In a new direction, Prof. Duncan and his students will expand their work to look at photofragment imaging of some interesting protonated systems to measure the bond energies for these weakly bound systems and to explore the tag-free spectroscopy of some of the ions. Professor Duncan will continue to collaborate with a wide range of theorists and experimentalists on these important chemical problems.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proton transfer processes are found throughout Chemistry and Biology, occurring in acid-base chemistry, electrochemistry, enzyme catalysis, hydrogen fuel cells, photosynthesis, etc.  In all of these situations, a molecular-level understanding of the chemistry is needed.  However, this is difficult to obtain in the hopelessly complex environment in solution, where bonding configurations change rapidly and many solvent molecules mediate the chemistry.  Our research program investigates individual protonated molecules, which form the basis of these processes, in the simplified environment of a molecular beam.  The experiment produces the ions in a vacuum, uses a mass spectrometer to select and identify their composition, and infrared laser spectroscopy complemented by computational quantum chemistry to determine their structures.  With these methods, the solvent or reaction partners can first be eliminated and then systematically re-introduced one molecule at a time to probe protonated structures and how they change with the environment.  Protonated ions, proton-bridging structures (which are intermediates in proton transfer), and water-solvated structures are investigated at the molecular level.  These model systems provide snapshots of molecular configurations along the proton transfer pathway and challenging benchmark systems for theory.

These measurements are conceptually simple, but their implementation and interpretation are technically demanding.  The isolation and selection of ions in a mass spectrometer provides their compositions, but necessitates that their concentrations are extremely low.  Successful experiments require optimized sources to produce and cool the ions, mass spectrometer designs to preserve their concentrations, and ultra-sensitive laser methods to measure their infrared spectroscopy.  Likewise, the spectral patterns for the exotic ions of interest are intrinsically complex, requiring state-of-the-art anharmonic theory for their interpretation.  We use second-order vibrational perturbation theory (VPT2) computations and also local mode calculations together with collaborator Prof. Anne McCoy (U. of Washington).  To enhance the available information, we have expanded the range of infrared wavelengths for these experiments to the near-IR to probe overtone and combination vibrations.  We have also designed, constructed and implemented a new kind of photofragment imaging instrument to investigate the decomposition pathways and energetics of these protonated ions.

These methods have been applied to several kinds of protonated molecules with different functional groups to determine the nature of proton binding sites and how the molecular structure is perturbed by the addition of a proton.  These include protonated forms of HCl, toluene, ethylenediamine, and acetyl-acetone.  Related experiments investigated the radical cations of formaldehyde, methanol, water and glyoxal, which can have intramolecular hydrogen atom shifts related to proton transfer.  To more directly probe proton transfer, we have studied proton-bound dimers (PBDs), which have a proton bridging two atoms or molecules, an intermediate in the proton transfer event.  The dimers studied include deceptively simple systems such as Ar-H+-Ar, and H2-H+-H2, up to more complex symmetric species (PBDs of water, CO, formaldehyde or ethylenediamine), and then on to asymmetric systems in which the proton bridges two molecules with different intrisic binding (proton affinity) values (e.g., acetyl-acetone with water, acetone with water).  In the acetyl-acetone/water system, we studied the effects of multiple-water solvation, finding spectroscopic evidence for the transfer of the proton from the organic moiety into the surrounding water.  In an unanticipated discovery, our study of water ions with attached argon led to the documentation of the ArOH+ cation as a new molecule with a strong (>50 kcal/mol) bond between argon and oxygen.  Our near-IR spectroscopy on protonated water clusters provided some of the first data for vibrational overtones and combinations in these important prototype systems.  These various molecular ion systems demonstrate that new chemistry can still be found for seemingly simple systems, and that the vibrational patterns for protonated molecular ions remain an elusive target for even the best state-of-the-art anharmonic theory methods.  The detailed spectroscopy reported here will hopefully provide benchmarks for the continued development of new anharmonic theory concepts and methods.

Six graduate students, three postdoctoral fellows, and five undergrad research students participated in this research, learning the chemistry, technology and culture of science through this work.  They each presented different aspects of the work at conferences and most of them were included as co-authors on the resulting publications.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Proton transfer processes are found throughout Chemistry and Biology, occurring in acid-base chemistry, electrochemistry, enzyme catalysis, hydrogen fuel cells, photosynthesis, etc. In all of these situations, a molecular-level understanding of the chemistry is needed. However, this is difficult to obtain in the hopelessly complex environment in solution, where bonding configurations change rapidly and many solvent molecules mediate the chemistry. Our research program investigates individual protonated molecules, which form the basis of these processes, in the simplified environment of a molecular beam. The experiment produces the ions in a vacuum, uses a mass spectrometer to select and identify their composition, and infrared laser spectroscopy complemented by computational quantum chemistry to determine their structures. With these methods, the solvent or reaction partners can first be eliminated and then systematically re-introduced one molecule at a time to probe protonated structures and how they change with the environment. Protonated ions, proton-bridging structures (which are intermediates in proton transfer), and water-solvated structures are investigated at the molecular level. These model systems provide snapshots of molecular configurations along the proton transfer pathway and challenging benchmark systems for theory. These measurements are conceptually simple, but their implementation and interpretation are technically demanding. The isolation and selection of ions in a mass spectrometer provides their compositions, but necessitates that their concentrations are extremely low. Successful experiments require optimized sources to produce and cool the ions, mass spectrometer designs to preserve their concentrations, and ultra-sensitive laser methods to measure their infrared spectroscopy. Likewise, the spectral patterns for the exotic ions of interest are intrinsically complex, requiring state-of-the-art anharmonic theory for their interpretation. We use second-order vibrational perturbation theory (VPT2) computations and also local mode calculations together with collaborator Prof. Anne McCoy (U. of Washington). To enhance the available information, we have expanded the range of infrared wavelengths for these experiments to the near-IR to probe overtone and combination vibrations. We have also designed, constructed and implemented a new kind of photofragment imaging instrument to investigate the decomposition pathways and energetics of these protonated ions. These methods have been applied to several kinds of protonated molecules with different functional groups to determine the nature of proton binding sites and how the molecular structure is perturbed by the addition of a proton. These include protonated forms of HCl, toluene, ethylenediamine, and acetyl-acetone. Related experiments investigated the radical cations of formaldehyde, methanol, water and glyoxal, which can have intramolecular hydrogen atom shifts related to proton transfer. To more directly probe proton transfer, we have studied proton-bound dimers (PBDs), which have a proton bridging two atoms or molecules, an intermediate in the proton transfer event. The dimers studied include deceptively simple systems such as Ar-H+-Ar, and H2-H+-H2, up to more complex symmetric species (PBDs of water, CO, formaldehyde or ethylenediamine), and then on to asymmetric systems in which the proton bridges two molecules with different intrisic binding (proton affinity) values (e.g., acetyl-acetone with water, acetone with water). In the acetyl-acetone/water system, we studied the effects of multiple-water solvation, finding spectroscopic evidence for the transfer of the proton from the organic moiety into the surrounding water. In an unanticipated discovery, our study of water ions with attached argon led to the documentation of the ArOH+ cation as a new molecule with a strong (>50 kcal/mol) bond between argon and oxygen. Our near-IR spectroscopy on protonated water clusters provided some of the first data for vibrational overtones and combinations in these important prototype systems. These various molecular ion systems demonstrate that new chemistry can still be found for seemingly simple systems, and that the vibrational patterns for protonated molecular ions remain an elusive target for even the best state-of-the-art anharmonic theory methods. The detailed spectroscopy reported here will hopefully provide benchmarks for the continued development of new anharmonic theory concepts and methods. Six graduate students, three postdoctoral fellows, and five undergrad research students participated in this research, learning the chemistry, technology and culture of science through this work. They each presented different aspects of the work at conferences and most of them were included as co-authors on the resulting publications. Last Modified: 10/08/2018 Submitted by: Michael A Duncan
